column4: Wesco offers to buy Anixter for $3 billion
column5: (Reuters) - Industrial parts supplier Wesco International Inc WCC.N said on Tuesday it is seeking to acquire Anixter International AXE.N and has most recently made an offer of $90 per share.
column6: This comes a day after Anixter, which supplies communications and security products, said it had agreed to a bid worth $86 per share and $2.50 per share contingent value rights from private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice.
column7: The equity value of Wesco’s bid for Anixter would be about $3 billion, according to Reuters calculations. Wesco’s per share offer is at a premium of 2.8% to the Anixter stock’s Monday close.
column8: Anixter said on Monday that CD&R also made a proposal to acquire all of Wesco’s outstanding shares, adding Wesco has determined that the proposal does not form a basis for discussions at this time. Wesco is yet to confirm any deal talks with CD&R.
column9: Earlier this month, Anixter disclosed that it had received a buyout offer of $90 per share, without naming the bidder.
column10: Anixter has a market value of $2.96 billion, while Wesco is valued at $2.33 billion, according to Refinitiv data.

column4: WESCO says it has made an offer to acquire Anixter
column5: Dec 24 (Reuters) - WESCO International Inc said on Tuesday that it is seeking to acquire Anixter International and has most recently made an offer of $90 per share.
column6: Anixter, which supplies communications and security products, had earlier received an offer from private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice to buy the company in a $4 billion deal.
column7: Earlier this month, Anixter disclosed that it had received a buyout offer without naming the party. (Reporting by Neha Malara in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Osram sells North American lighting business to WESCO International
column5: FRANKFURT (Reuters) - U.S.-based WESCO International WCC.N has agreed to buy the North American services unit of German lighting group Osram OSRn.DE for less than 100 million euros ($114 million), the groups said on Wednesday.
column6: The sale of Sylvania Lighting Solutions, which makes annual sales of more than $100 million and employs about 220 staff, is expected to close in the first quarter of 2019, Osram said, adding it was making further progress in its transformation.
column7: “Osram is increasingly focusing on intelligent technologies in the field of visible and invisible light for the market fields of visualization, sensor technology and treatment,” the group said.
column8: Sylvania Lighting Solutions had been on the block since May last year. Its sale will not have a significant impact on Osram’s balance sheet, the group said.
